subject: Re: [junit] test cases for inputs from file
msgSnippet: My concurrency knowledge is less than it should be. Could you provide sample code for this? I assume you meant this: class MyTestFixture extends TestCase
messageBody:
My concurrency knowledge is less than it should be. Could you provide
sample code for this? I assume you meant this:

class MyTestFixture extends TestCase
setUp:
synchronized (MyTestFixture.class) {
// set up code
}

tearDown:
synchronized (MyTestFixture.class) {
// tear down code
}

testX:
synchronized (MyTestFixture.class) {
// test code
}

Thanks.

>> On a number of occasions I have written a TestCase where setUp()
>> creates an object that uses the file system and tearDown() clears
the
>> entire tree used by that object. I have never successfully had
>> tearDown() finish before setUp() started for the next test, owing to
>> the fact (I suppose) that the JVM does not block on the system call.
>>
>> I ended up doing what you suggest: I use a different root directory
for
>> each test, usually calling it something like
>>
>> root-<testClassName>-<testName>
>>
>> I then add a shutdown hook to clean them all up.
>
>I have a similar test situation where I am testing agasinst a smart
card
>and
>my solution
>was to synchronize on my test fixture in setUp(), tearDown() and each
test
>case. This ensured that my tests ran synchronously and that the smart
card
>was properly cleaned up before the next test started.
>
>>
>> Has anyone used Prevayler? If so, have you come up with any
strategies
>> for unit testing against the Prevayler without changing its source?
I
>> have been considering refactoring Prevayler to talk to byte streams
and
>> having one wrapper around it that uses the file system for
production
>> and another wrapper that keeps everything in memory for test.
>>
>> *********** REPLY SEPARATOR ***********
